articles.headline: Santorum and Romney Court Blue-Collar Voters in Ohio
articles.snippet: Republicans began voting in 10 states on Tuesday, with Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum engaged in a particularly competitive primary fight in Ohio.
articles.abstract: Republicans began voting in 10 states on Tuesday, with Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum engaged in a particularly competitive primary fight in Ohio.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZANESVILLE, Ohio — If Mitt Romney defeats Rick Santorum in the bellwether primary here on Tuesday, it will be in no small part because he managed to win over one of the most hotly contested and elusive segments of the electorate: white working-class voters.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Obama Presses Netanyahu to Resist Strikes on Iran
articles.snippet: At the White House, President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu came to little agreement on confronting Iran over its nuclear capabilities.
articles.abstract: At the White House, President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu came to little agreement on confronting Iran over its nuclear capabilities.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With Israel warning of a possible military strike on Iran’s nuclear facilities, President Obama urged Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu at the White House on Monday to give diplomacy and economic sanctions a chance to work before resorting to military action.

articles.headline: In China, Sobering Signs of Slower Growth
articles.snippet: The Chinese economy, after nearly three decades of rapid, almost uninterrupted growth, seems to be settling down.
articles.abstract: The Chinese economy, after nearly three decades of rapid, almost uninterrupted growth, seems to be settling down.
articles.lead_paragraph: GUANGZHOU, China — The nights are a little darker now here in the main metropolis of southeastern China, at the center of one of the country’s largest export hubs.

articles.headline: Digital Records May Not Cut Health Costs, Study Cautions
articles.snippet: Researchers found that doctors using electronic records ordered expensive imaging tests more often than those relying on paper records.
articles.abstract: Researchers found that doctors using electronic records ordered expensive imaging tests more often than those relying on paper records.
articles.lead_paragraph: Computerized patient records are unlikely to cut health care costs and may actually encourage doctors to order expensive tests more often, a study published on Monday concludes.

articles.headline: After Ratings Drop, Ford Reworks Touch Screens
articles.snippet: Ford added touch-screen controls ahead of its competitors, but the flaws hurt its reputation and its rating from Consumer Reports.
articles.abstract: Ford added touch-screen controls ahead of its competitors, but the flaws hurt its reputation and its rating from Consumer Reports.
articles.lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich. — The Ford Motor Company began adding touch-screen control systems to some of its most popular models two years ago as a way to stand out from the rest of the industry and draw in new customers.

articles.headline: At Tribe’s Door, a Hub of Beer and Heartache
articles.snippet: The Oglala Sioux Tribe is suing large brewers and stores in neighboring Whiteclay, Neb., that the tribe says encourage illegal alcohol consumption.
articles.abstract: The Oglala Sioux Tribe is suing large brewers and stores in neighboring Whiteclay, Neb., that the tribe says encourage illegal alcohol consumption.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHITECLAY, Neb. — Four rickety metal shacks that line the main road in this town of maybe 10 people sell an average of 13,000 cans of beer and malt liquor a day. The nearest sizable city is two hours north. But just 240 yards north — across the state line in South Dakota — is the sprawling Pine Ridge Indian Reservation, where alcohol has been banned since the 1970s.

articles.headline: Cato Institute Is Caught in a Rift Over Its Direction
articles.snippet: The Cato Institute says that Charles Koch’s Republican activism threatens its reputation for independent research.
articles.abstract: The Cato Institute says that Charles Koch’s Republican activism threatens its reputation for independent research.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — From its perch in a spacious brand-new headquarters blocks from the White House, the Cato Institute has built on its reputation as a venerable libertarian research center unafraid to cross party lines.

articles.headline: India’s Supreme Court to Hear Dispute on Drug Patents
articles.snippet: India’s mass production of generic versions of drugs patented elsewhere helps poor people with treatment that would otherwise be too costly, but drug companies say the knockoffs stifle innovation.
articles.abstract: India’s mass production of generic versions of drugs patented elsewhere helps poor people with treatment that would otherwise be too costly, but drug companies say the knockoffs stifle innovation.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — While China was becoming the world’s shop floor, India took its place as the world’s pharmacy, and in recent decades has been the largest provider of cheap, lifesaving medicines in poor countries across the globe.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Andrew Pollack
